newsitem.title: UK: INTERVIEW - Booker/Nurdin deal will mean job cuts.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Booker/Nurdin deal will mean job cuts.

text.p: The planned merger between food wholesalers Booker Plc and Nurdin & Peacock Plc will mean job cuts and cash-and-carry outlet closures.
Booker chief executive Charles Bowen said jobs would go as a result of the closure of about 40 cash-and-carry warehouses and head office rationalisation, but he declined to give more details.
"There will be around 40 depot closures, but we can't talk about the number of jobs," he said in a telephone interview.
He said if the deal goes ahead it would take about three years to complete the rationalisation of the businesses.
Earlier Booker announced an agreed bid for Nurdin, valuing the food wholesaler at 264 million stg.
Bowen said Booker had told private Dutch company SHV Makro, which has a 14 percent stake in Nurdin, of the bid, but had had no response. Last year Nurdin rejected a merger offer from SHV.

Bowen said the wholesaling business -- which supplies caterers and independent retailers -- had come under increasing pressure from supermarkets, discount retailers such as Aldi and Lidl as well as delivered wholesalers.
He said the combined businesses would have a market share of about 22 percent. -- London Newsroom + 44 171 542 7717
